utterances: The fewer people we have in the store, the louder I play the music.
(Soundbite of laughter)
(Soundbite of music)
Music, marketing - Giarrusso's even got his staff using mind games to try and boost sales and spirits.
Unidentified Bowl & Board Employee: Have you heard about our sale?
Unidentified Female Shopper #1: No, first time, I'm looking around.
But Bowl & Board's news is bad.
Sales have sunk 30 percent, and Giarrusso has cut to the bone, slashing everything from employees to their health insurance.
He's even started giving customers their purchases without a bag.
I trained all my employees that the motion is, create it like it's not an option.
Wrap it up, here you go, and go right onto the next customer.
Ultimately, Giarrusso knows the nickel-and-dime-ing isn't going to do it.
He's seriously behind in rent at two of his three stores, and he's late with many of his vendors, who are now refusing to sell him more product until he pays up.
How are you?
Unidentified Female Shopper #2: Good.
Would you have a curtain rod for a bathtub?
Yeah, we should.
We did.
We're at a very dangerous moment, where your lack of inventory starts affects your sales.
I don't see - yeah, we're out.
Unidentified Female Shopper #2: OK.
Sorry about that.
Unidentified Female Shopper #2: That's all right.
Thanks.
A month ago, I'd be screaming, where are the shower rods?
You know, this is like milk for a convenience store.
Don't want to be without, right?
Today, however, it's just another of the many challenges of surviving a recession.
I certainly hope so.
I certainly hope so.
Because Ghana has been, as I said, a steady force in terms of progress in Africa, and in terms of hope for Africa.
So I do hope that this will educate some people throughout the world, in America and elsewhere, about Ghana and about Africa.
All right, Meri, real quick.
I know that you lived much of your life here in the United States; you're a native Ghanaian.
Talk to me about any tug, pull yesterday, if at all.
Well, you know, my daughter and I went to Don's Place(ph), which is a sports bar - a very popular sports bar in town to watch it.
And when the Ghana National Anthem was played - it was the first of the two national anthems to be played - everyone in the bar was almost screaming the national anthem at the top of their lungs.
And then the U.S.
National Anthem started playing and my daughter and I started singing it and then people kind of looked at us like, who are you here to root for?
(Soundbite of laughter)
So that was a moment of uh-oh, better shut-up now.
Well, the fun in the streets continues.
We can hear it behind you, Meri Danquar.
We appreciate the time.
And good luck to the Ghanaian team.
Thank you very much, Ed.
Thanks for having me.
With President Bush meeting Democratic leaders today to talk about Iraq, the news from Baghdad is very bad.
Five car bombs exploded today, killing about 150 people, injuring more than 200.
Earlier, I talked with NPR's Mike Shuster about the violence in the city.
It seemed to go from the southwest through the center of Baghdad and into the northeast.
These bombs hit mostly Shiite neighborhoods and Shiite markets.
And they were just devastating and just built all afternoon.
And then the one that was the worst was in the Sadriyah market in north central Baghdad, and it happened around 4:00 in the afternoon.
This was when people were going to the market toward the end of the afternoon.
It was a terrible day today, Alex.
This market has already been the site of at least one bombing, hasn't it?
That's right.
It was the site not too long ago of a devastating bombing with an even larger death toll than the one today, if you can imagine that.
And there were already workers in this market that were rebuilding it, and some of them may have been killed as well today.
So can you tell, Mike, if these bombings today are coordinated in some way, or are these all individual insurgent attacks that happened to go off on the same day?
Alex, honestly, there's no way of answering that question definitively without someone or some group taking responsibility and making that claim.
But it certainly feels like there is a coordinated onslaught, not everyday, but there are days like today when there are multiple bombings.

They happen against largely Shiite targets, and it does feel like there is someone planning these to go off in sequence, not quite simultaneously, but in order to emphasize the onslaught in Baghdad, and perhaps clearly challenge the security crackdown that the United States and the Iraqi forces put into place and have been putting further into place over the last two months.
Mike, what is happening with the situation with the government in Baghdad?
And people may have missed this with all the news concentration on the Virginia Tech shootings.
But a couple of days ago, the anti-American religious and political leader Moqtada al-Sadr ordered his party members to quit the government of Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki.
What they did is there were six ministries of Maliki's cabinet that were under the control of Sadr's people, and he ordered them to leave those government posts.
But he did not order the 30 or so members of parliament that he has the support of to leave the Maliki coalition, let's say, or the Maliki majority in parliament.
So this wasn't a step that has brought the Maliki government down.
And there are disagreements in Baghdad on what kind of effect that it may have on the Maliki government.

Some see it as destabilizing, and it seems that Sadr himself wanted to weaken the government because he was unhappy with Maliki's unwillingness to demand that the United States set a timetable for the withdrawal of U.S.
troops here.
But at the same time, Sadr and his people are not known as those who can manage their ministries well.
And so some people think that when Maliki finally gets around to appointing new ministers to these ministries, they may be better run and in fact his government might be a bit more stable.
We'll have to wait and see.
We all look for signs on whether the surge of U.S.
forces in Baghdad is working.
Military people say we won't really know the answer to that for months and months, but people really are going to interpret a day like today badly.
Oh, there's no question about it.

In the last week, when the parliament was bombed and one of the bridges in Baghdad collapsed from that enormous truck bomb, this is the kind of things that hits the city psychologically, hits the leaders psychologically, and of course this is going to be interpreted back in the United States psychologically.
Now, you can't tell whether the increased security operation in Baghdad is really working.

The military says that the number of deaths has gone down, but when you see data like today, no one's going to think that it's any more safe to move around Baghdad and to live in Baghdad than it was before this crackdown started.
NPR's Mike Shuster with us again from Baghdad.
Mike, thank you.
You're welcome, Alex.
I'm Ed Gordon.
This is News & Notes.
NPR Senior Correspondent Juan Williams is here with his Beltway insiders.
Today's Political Corner focuses on white candidates and black running mates, also, on the ongoing battle over voting rights.
Juan, over to you.
Thanks, Ed.
I'm joined now by Donna Brazile, former campaign manager for Democratic presidential nominee Al Gore in 2000.
Donna now runs her own political consulting firm in Washington.
And also with us is Reverend Joseph Watkins, member of the Government Relations Committee at Buchanan Ingersoll, and a member of the first President Bush's White House staff.
Reverend Watkins joins us from our NPR Bureau in New York.
Thanks for joining me.
Thanks, Juan.
I think it is a top priority for us to stamp out al-Qaeda once and for all.
And I think capturing or killing bin Laden is a critical aspect of stamping out al-Qaeda.
He's not just a symbol.
He's also the operational leader of an organization that's planning attacks against U.S.
targets.
But could an Obama administration really do anything new and different in pursuing Osama bin Laden?
NPR's intelligence correspondent, Tom Gjelten, is here now.
And, Tom, what is President-elect Obama's plan for going after al-Qaeda?
Well, Madeleine, the first thing is that he says that he would refocus the U.S.
effort to put more attention on that objective.
He always talks about this in the context of getting out of Iraq and turning attention to al-Qaeda instead.
What we hear often is that the Bush administration took its eyes off the ball.
